title: FTSE 100 jumps into the green after Wall Street boom despite ongoing China fears
text:
FTSE 100 jumps into the green after Wall Street boom despite ongoing China fears FTSE 100 jumps into the green after Wall Street boom despite ongoing China fears LONDON's premier share index has today had its best day of trading since 2011, but experts warned of more wild volatility ahead amid ongoing fears over China. PUBLISHED: 17:10, Thu, Aug 27, 2015 | UPDATED: 17:16, Thu, Aug 27, 2015 REUTERS Global stock market have been in turmoil over China fears 
The FTSE 100 Index finished up by 3.7 per cent on Thursday, after Wall Street rocketed higher last night and markets in Asia rebounded. Britain's blue chip index had closed down by 1.7 per cent yesterday, losing almost £30billion, after another torrid day of trading that followed ' Black Monday' . But the Dow Jones Industrial Average in America soared more than 600 points, or four per cent, in its steepest rally for nearly four years on Wednesday. The session broke a six-day run of closing in the red, which included Monday's record one day falls, and helped boost confidence in London today. 
Laith Khalaf, senior analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, said: "It’s been one of the best ever days for the UK stock market, neatly illustrating why it’s a bad idea to sell out in a market rout. 
"Black Monday was a truly dreadful day for stock investors, but it’s been followed by big bounce, with the FTSE now back where it ended last week. 
"Markets tend to over-react to both good and bad news, so sharp falls are often followed by strong rallies." Related articles Savers warned over 'catastrophic' effects of falling markets on... 
Markets in the US appear to have been calmed by comments made by one of the members of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), which sets interest rates in America. William C. Dudley suggested that a rate rise in the US is likely to have been pushed back from its expected lift in September. But experts warned that with worries remaining over China's economy, the rally could prove to be short-lived.Tony Cross, market analyst at Trustnet Direct, said: "Volatility like this doesn't tend to disappear fast and with volumes set to thin out ahead of the long weekend, there's certainly the prospect of seeing more big moves in the near term."China's Shanghai Composite Index, whose 8.5 per cent drop on Monday triggered a global sell-off, raced 5.3 per cent higher in its biggest gain for eight weeks, while the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong surged more than 3.5 per cent.Markets have endured some of the worst volatility since the financial crisis amid fears over China's slowing economy, which saw the country slash its interest rates for the fifth time in nine months earlier this week.Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said: "Certainly Mr Dudley’s comments show that US policymakers have serious concerns about events in China and the potential ripple out effects…"Just because we’ve seen the best one day US stock market performance since 2011, its going to take a few more days like yesterday to restore confidence to a market that has had to endure more twists and turns than a corkscrew."
